title:
Relativistic Low Angular Momentum Advective Flows onto Black Hole and
  associated observational signatures
abstract:
We present simulation results examining the presence and behavior of standing
shocks in zero-energy low angular momentum advective accretion flows and
explore their (in)stabilities properties taking into account various specific
angular momentum, $\lambda_0$. Within the range $10-50R_g$ (where $R_g$ denotes
the Schwarzschild radius), shocks are discernible for $\lambda_0\geq 1.75$. In
the special relativistic hydrodynamic (RHD) simulation when $\lambda_0 = 1.80$,
we find the merger of two shocks resulted in a dramatic increase in luminosity.
We present the impact of external and internal flow collisions from the funnel
region on luminosity. Notably, oscillatory behavior characterizes shocks within
$1.70 \leq \lambda_0 \leq 1.80$. Using free-free emission as a proxy for
analysis, we shows that the luminosity oscillations between frequencies of
$0.1-10$ Hz for $\lambda_0$ range $1.7 \leq \lambda_0 \leq 1.80$. These
findings offer insights into quasi-periodic oscillations emissions from certain
black hole X-ray binaries, exemplified by GX 339-4. Furthermore, for the
supermassive black hole at the Milky Way's center, Sgr A*, oscillation
frequencies between $10^{-6}$ and $10^{-5}$ Hz were observed. This frequency
range, translating to one cycle every few days, aligns with observational data
from the X-ray telescopes such as Chandra, Swift, and XMM-Newton.
